entry.title: Multithreading principle
entry.content:
I will try to demonstrate how multithreading works? In other words, how OS, CPU, memory, registers join together to implement multithreading?

When you first take a peek of multithreading, you should know what does it existed for, then you know how to multithread in every programming language, well, you meet the its syntax, yet you donâ€™t know how the function was implemented, they encapsulate the function into API12, only you look up the the manual then you know whatâ€™s this function is used for, whatâ€™s its input parameters and return value. The API still doesnâ€™t help you know the working mechanism, if you donâ€™t go through the source code, which is based on the principle of multithreading.

Why do you need to know the principle? Well, because you need to fully understand it then you can write your own API to implement multithreading.

Why do you need to write your own API? because only you know every detail then your knowledge become transformative enough, thatâ€™s how you adapt your knowledge to solve the real world problem and dig further.

How are threads scheduled to physical CPUs?

Well, the OS sets the physical CPU registers to the appropriate values and jumps to the location where the thread was last interrupted (which in effect sets the instruction pointer). At this point the OS has lost control and is no longer involved. It can only regain control if a hardware interrupt occurs or some other physical CPU core decides to take control of the CPU.

What is HTTP?
The Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) is designed to enable communications between clients and servers.
HTTP works as a request-response protocol between a client and server.
A web browser may be the client, and an application on a computer that hosts a web site may be the server.
Example: A client (browser) submits an HTTP request to the server; then the server returns a response to the client. The response contains status information about the request and may also contain the requested content
